Title: PERFORMANCE INSOLES REDEFINED: INTRODUCING RUN PACER ELITE
Author: Superfeet User
Body HTML:
The newest innovation in running isn’t a shoe, it’s inside one. Introducing Run Pacer Elite, a breakthrough insole featuring a unique carbon fiber plate and advanced supercritical foam that together amplify every stride with unmatched propulsion, responsiveness, and comfort.

At Superfeet, we’re proud of our long history leading the industry in underfoot solutions and using sports science to create insoles that power performance for athletes at every level. Run Pacer Elite joins our comprehensive lineup of running insoles trusted by Olympians, marathoners, casual runners and everyone in between to deliver the support and comfort they need in every step. But Run Pacer Elite isn’t just an insole, it’s an edge.

WHAT MAKES RUN PACER ELITE DIFFERENT?

At the core of Run Pacer Elite is our most advanced technology pairing yet: a Carbitex® carbon fiber plate and SuperRev™ foam. Together, the combined technologies unlock 39% more responsiveness, compared to traditional insoles or shoes alone, giving every runner the opportunity to feel fast on demand.

The Carbitex dynamically flexible carbon fiber plate is precision-calibrated to adapt with every pace. Unlike stiff, restrictive plates, Carbitex works with the body by engaging stiffness as it bends, providing geared power at higher speeds while remaining highly flexible at slower speeds, ensuring a natural ride at easy paces while unleashing explosive propulsion during faster speeds.

Complementing this propulsion is the all-new SuperRev foam, created via a supercritical process infusing advanced foams with high-pressure CO2 and nitrogen to create a unique microcellular structure. The result: maximum energy return, lightweight responsiveness, and durable comfort that cushions every landing while powering runners into their next stride.

WHO IS RUN PACER ELITE FOR?

Run Pacer Elite may be our most advanced insole, but you don’t need a sub-five-minute mile to reap the benefits of greater energy return and responsiveness. The unique flexibility of the Carbitex carbon fiber plate meets you at your pace and powers you through every stride, whether you’re training for your first 5K or running your tenth marathon. Of course, pros love what Run Pacer Elite can add to their workouts and races as well.

Olympian and newest Superfeet athlete Colleen Quigley recently had a chance to test out a pair. “I can really feel the carbon fiber bounce,” she noted. “The plate gives an incredible pop when I pick up speed. There is also a nice, cushioned feel that feels smooth and supportive that makes every step feel effortless.”

PUSH YOUR PACE

Run Pacer Elite is built for athletes who give everything they’ve got in every step. With max energy return and adaptive carbon fiber, the more you put in, the more you get out. No matter your pace, Run Pacer Elite can help you push it beyond limits.

“Run Pacer Elite brings to life our unwavering commitment to serve runners with innovative solutions that elevate their performance,” said Matt Gooch, VP of Product and Innovation at Superfeet. “We’ve reimagined the insole from a simple accessory into a hidden underfoot advantage.”
Summary HTML:
The latest revolution in running gear isn’t a shoe—it’s what’s inside it. Meet Run Pacer Elite, Superfeet’s cutting-edge insole engineered to elevate every stride. Featuring a dynamic carbon fiber plate paired with advanced supercritical foam, this innovation delivers exceptional propulsion, responsiveness, and comfort.

Backed by decades of sports science and trusted by Olympians, marathoners, and everyday runners alike, Superfeet continues to lead the way in performance-driven underfoot solutions. With Run Pacer Elite, runners gain more than support—they gain an edge.

Title: OLYMPIAN COLLEEN QUIGLEY JOINS TEAM SUPERFEET
Author: Superfeet User
Body HTML:
She’s an Olympic steeplechaser, NCAA national champion, pro runner, mental health advocate, and now Colleen Quigley can add Superfeet Athlete to her list of titles. We’re thrilled to welcome her to the team! She embodies the Superfeet mission in everything she does, through both her incredible achievements on the track and her dedication to community off it. Colleen knows that when you take care of your body and your mind, you can accomplish more than you ever imagined. We can’t wait to see what she does next.

Read the full press release announcement below.


FERNDALE, Wash. — Superfeet, the global leader in performance insoles, is expanding its growing athlete roster by adding Colleen Quigley. Known for her dedication to sport and community, Quigley embodies the holistic athlete ethos at the heart of Superfeet.

Quigley – a 2016 Olympian in the 3,000-meter steeplechase, NCAA national champion, nine-time All-American and 2025 inductee in the Florida State University Athletics Hall of Fame – has built her career on passion, versatility and perseverance. From her unconventional beginnings as a dancer and model to becoming one of America’s top middle-distance runners, her journey proves it’s never too late to chase the sport’s highest stage through hard work and dedication. Today, she is both a competitor and a community leader, serving as a role model for modern athletes who view peak performance as part of a well-rounded lifestyle.

“This partnership is about more than sport,” says Trip Randall, CEO of Superfeet. “Colleen represents performance with perspective: she’s an Olympian, a mentor and an advocate for mental health and balance. Her story aligns perfectly with Superfeet’s mission: Designed for movement. Built to change lives.”

Beyond her own racing, Quigley is strengthening the sport through Meridia, a women-led, athlete-owned professional track team she co-founded earlier this year. Meridia is reimagining how athletes are supported, offering revenue-sharing, athlete autonomy, and a holistic infrastructure both on and off the track to help athletes succeed.

“Performance isn’t always a straight path; it’s about showing up, adapting, and finding strength in the details,” Quigley says. “I’m excited to partner with a brand that shares my passion for empowering athletes at every level.”

This new partnership comes as Superfeet pursues a renewed mission to serve athletes through biomechanical innovation and intentional design. Quigley joins fellow Olympian Sanya Richards-Ross on the brand’s growing athlete team, reinforcing its athlete-first mindset. To follow along this new partnership, follow us on social media @Superfeet.

Colleen knows that when you take care of your body and your mind, you can accomplish more than you ever imagined. We can’t wait to see what she does next.

Title: Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome: Find Relief With Superfeet Insoles
Author: Carla Vargas
Body HTML:
Tarsal tunnel syndrome is a painful condition that affects the foot and ankle. It occurs when the tibial nerve, which runs along the inside of the ankle, becomes compressed or squeezed.  

This compression can lead to pain, numbness, and tingling in the foot and toes. 

The tarsal tunnel is a narrow space on the inside of the ankle. It's formed by bone on one side and a thick ligament on the other. Several important structures pass through this tunnel, including blood vessels, tendons, and the tibial nerve. When this nerve gets squeezed, it can cause a range of uncomfortable symptoms. 

Pain like this can hinder movement and slow you down. Our goal at Superfeet is to get you walking, running, and living again, as pain-free as possible. 

Causes of Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome 

Tarsal tunnel syndrome can be caused by various factors that put pressure on the tibial nerve. One common cause is flat feet or fallen arches. When the foot's arch collapses, it can stretch the tibial nerve and lead to compression. 

Injuries to the ankle, such as sprains or fractures, can also cause tarsal tunnel syndrome. These injuries can lead to swelling that puts pressure on the nerve. In some cases, ganglion cysts or other soft tissue growths near the tarsal tunnel can compress the nerve. 

Certain medical conditions can increase the risk of developing tarsal tunnel syndrome. These include diabetes, which can cause nerve damage, and arthritis, which can lead to inflammation in the ankle joint. Varicose veins near the tarsal tunnel can also put pressure on the tibial nerve. 

Sometimes, tarsal tunnel syndrome can be caused by repetitive stress. Activities that involve prolonged standing, walking, or running can irritate the tibial nerve over time. This is why the condition is mostly seen in athletes or people with jobs that require a lot of time on their feet. 

Symptoms of Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome 

The symptoms of tarsal tunnel syndrome can vary from person to person, but there are some common signs to look out for—pain is, of course, the first symptom people notice. It's usually felt on the inside of the ankle and can extend into the arch of the foot. 

Numbness and tingling are also common symptoms. 

In some cases, people with tarsal tunnel syndrome may experience weakness in their foot muscles. This can make it difficult to move the toes or maintain balance while walking.  

When dealing with symptoms like pain and weakness, insoles can be a game-changer.  

Preventing Tarsal Tunnel Syndrome 

Prevention: this is where the benefits of Superfeet insoles really shine. The supportive shape and stabilizing structure help your feet in their nature shape which can go a long way toward helping reduce pain, numbness, and tingling. 

For athletes or people with jobs that involve a lot of standing or walking, proper footwear is crucial. Your shoes and insoles should provide good arch support and cushioning. It's also important to replace your shoes regularly, as worn-out shoes can contribute to foot problems. 

Stretching exercises for your feet and ankles can help keep them flexible and reduce the risk of injury. If you're starting a new exercise program, it's important to increase your activity level gradually to give your feet and ankles time to adapt. 

By taking these preventive measures and being aware of the early signs of tarsal tunnel syndrome, you can help keep your feet healthy and pain-free. Remember, if you do experience persistent foot pain or numbness, it's always best to consult with a healthcare professional for proper diagnosis and treatment. 

Whether you struggle with tarsal tunnel syndrome, another condition, or are simply looking to keep your feet and ankles strong and healthy, Superfeet insoles can help power your every move. 

Written in consultation with and reviewed by Superfeet Biomechanics and Education team members Meredith Wells, PhD and Justin Wager, PhD
Summary HTML: Tarsal tunnel syndrome causes pain, numbness, and tingling from nerve compression in the ankle. Superfeet insoles can help reduce strain, support natural foot alignment, and ease symptoms.

Title: Work Boot Insoles That Fight Fatigue, Even on Concrete Floors
Author: Carla Vargas
Body HTML:
For millions of workers who spend their days on unforgiving concrete surfaces, foot fatigue isn't just discomfort—it's a daily reality that can impact productivity, health, and overall quality of life.  

The good news? Superfeet insoles can transform your workday experience, providing the support and cushioning your body desperately needs. 

The Hidden Cost of Concrete: Why Your Feet Pay the Price 

Standing and walking on concrete for extended periods subjects your body to relentless, high-impact forces. Unlike natural terrain that offers some degree of shock absorption, concrete provides no give, sending jarring impacts directly from your feet to your lower back. 

Research confirms this widespread workplace challenge. Workers spending extended hours on hard floors frequently report increased discomfort, with approximately two-thirds of surveyed distribution center workers experiencing lower extremity symptoms. Many of these workers take over 1000 steps per hour on concrete, creating a direct link between tibial shock exposure and foot and knee pain. 

The Domino Effect: How Concrete Impacts Your Entire Body 

The consequences of prolonged concrete exposure extend far beyond simple foot soreness: 

Immediate Effects:

  • Foot fatigue and soreness from overworked muscles
  • Pressure buildup on the plantar surface
  • Increased strain on leg muscles and joints 

 Progressive Conditions: 

  • Plantar fasciitis: Inflammation of the tissue connecting heel to toes
  • Metatarsalgia: Pain and inflammation in the ball of the foot
  • Heel spurs: Bony protrusions from chronic plantar fasciitis
  • Bunions and corns: Deformities from improper foot mechanics 

 Systemic Impact: 

  • Shin splints and ankle pain
  • Knee, hip, and lower back discomfort
  • Poor posture and altered gait patterns
  • Reduced productivity and increased sick days 

Essential Features: What Makes Superfeet Insoles Superior 

When selecting work boot insoles that fight fatigue, even on concrete floors, several critical design elements separate premium options from basic alternatives: 

1. Structured Arch Support 

Proper arch support distributes body weight evenly across your entire foot, preventing excessive pressure on heel and forefoot areas. Superfeet's biomechanical design provides the rigid support structure your arches need, regardless of whether you have low, medium, or high natural arches. 

2. Deep Heel Cup Technology 

A deep heel cup cradles your heel, providing stability and preventing excessive foot motion that leads to fatigue. This feature maximizes shock absorption at heel strike—crucial for conditions like plantar fasciitis and heel spurs. 

3. Strategic Cushioning Zones 

Superfeet insoles place cushioning precisely where impact forces are greatest: the heel and forefoot. 

4. Biomechanical Alignment 

Beyond cushioning, Superfeet insoles promote proper foot and ankle function. This biomechanical support extends benefits throughout your body, reducing strain on knees, hips, and lower back while improving overall movement efficiency. 

Dynamic vs. Static Support: Understanding Your Options 

Research reveals important differences between static and dynamic insole designs: 

Static Insoles provide firm, unchanging support that maintains foot alignment and distributes pressure consistently. These excel in providing structural stability and are often preferred for severe alignment issues. 

Dynamic Insoles feature conforming elements that adapt to foot movement and pressure changes. Studies show dynamic insoles in work boots can provide additional reductions in tibial shock compared to static versions, especially at faster walking speeds. 

Superfeet combines elements of both approaches, providing structured support where needed while incorporating adaptive comfort technology in high-impact zones. 

Addressing Specific Foot Conditions with Targeted Solutions 

Different foot types and conditions require specialized approaches: 

For Plantar Fasciitis and Heel Spurs 

Look for insoles with substantial heel cushioning and strong arch support to reduce plantar fascia tension. Deep heel cups are particularly beneficial for absorbing heel strike impact. 

For High Arches 

Pronounced, semi-rigid arch support helps distribute weight evenly, preventing instability and overpronation that leads to fatigue and discomfort. 

For Flat Feet 

Moderate arch support that's firm enough to provide structure without causing pressure points works best. Full-length cushioning ensures shock absorption across the entire foot surface. 

Beyond Fatigue Relief: The Comprehensive Benefits 

The correct premium insoles offer advantages extending far beyond comfort: 

Injury Prevention 

Proper support and shock absorption significantly reduce overuse injury risk common in concrete-heavy occupations. 

Enhanced Productivity 

Comfortable workers maintain focus and energy throughout their shifts, experiencing less downtime due to discomfort-related issues. 

Long-term Health Benefits 

Correcting biomechanical imbalances early prevents progressive conditions that could impact your career longevity and quality of life. 

Equipment Longevity 

Quality insoles reduce uneven boot wear by correcting gait abnormalities and distributing impact forces more evenly. 

Why Superfeet Leads the Industry 

At Superfeet, we conduct extensive research and testing in podiatric science and biomechanical engineering. Our work boot insoles combine: 

  • Structured support that maintains foot positioning
  • Deep heel cup technology for maximum stability
  • Adaptive comfort materials that respond to your specific needs
  • Proven durability that withstands demanding work environments 

Our commitment to scientific design and quality materials makes Superfeet the preferred choice for workers who refuse to compromise on foot health and comfort. 

Written in consultation with and reviewed by Superfeet Biomechanics and Education team members Meredith Wells, PhD and Justin Wager, PhD
Summary HTML: Working long hours on concrete floors can take a toll on your feet and body. Superfeet insoles provide arch support, cushioning, and stability to fight fatigue and protect against long-term pain.

Title: Outside Foot Pain: How to Manage It with Superfeet Insoles and Avoid Surgery
Author: Carla Vargas
Body HTML:
Lateral foot pain refers to discomfort or aching on the outer edge of your foot. This type of pain can make walking, running, or even standing uncomfortable. Many people experience this issue, and it can stem from various causes. 

The outer part of your foot is made up of several bones, ligaments, and tendons. When any of these structures become injured or inflamed, you may feel pain along the side of your foot. This pain can range from a dull ache to a sharp, stabbing sensation. 

It's important to note that lateral foot pain isn't just a minor inconvenience. If left untreated, it can lead to changes in your gait, which may cause problems in other parts of your body, like your knees, hips, or back. 

Common Causes of Lateral Foot Pain 

There are several reasons why you might experience pain on the outside of your foot. Understanding these causes can help you identify the problem and seek appropriate treatment.  

One common cause is peroneal tendonitis. This condition occurs when the tendons that run along the outer part of your ankle become inflamed. Overuse, sudden increases in activity, or wearing shoes that don't provide proper support can lead to this condition. 

Another frequent cause of outer foot pain is a stress fracture, which is a tiny crack in one of the bones in your foot, often caused by repetitive force or sudden increases in exercise intensity. Stress fractures can be particularly common in athletes, or anyone who spends a lot of time on their feet. 

Ankle sprains can also lead to lateral foot pain. When you roll your ankle outward, it can stretch or tear the ligaments on the outer part of your foot, causing pain and swelling. 

A lot of these causes can be prevented by wearing proper footwear and insoles. Superfeet insoles are a great way to protect your feet by providing added support and stability, helping reduce pain. 

Symptoms Associated with Lateral Foot Pain 

Recognizing the signs and symptoms of conditions that cause lateral foot pain can help you seek treatment. The most obvious sign is pain along the outer edge of your foot, but there are other symptoms to watch for as well. 

Swelling is often present, especially if the pain is due to an injury or inflammation. You might notice that the outer part of your foot looks puffy or feels warm to the touch. 

Many people with lateral foot pain also experience stiffness in their foot, particularly in the morning or after periods of rest. This stiffness might make it difficult to move your foot or toes normally. 

In some cases, you might hear or feel a popping or clicking sensation when you move your foot. This could indicate a problem with the tendons or ligaments in your foot. 

Diagnosing Lateral Foot Pain 

If you're experiencing persistent pain on the outside of your foot, it's important to see a healthcare provider for a proper diagnosis. They will likely start by asking about your symptoms and medical history. 

Your doctor will probably perform a physical examination of your foot. They'll look for signs of swelling, feel for tender spots, and check your foot's range of motion. They might also ask you to walk or perform certain movements to see how your foot functions. 

In some cases, imaging tests might be necessary. X-rays can show bone fractures or other skeletal abnormalities. MRI or ultrasound scans can provide more detailed images of the soft tissues in your foot, helping to identify problems with tendons or ligaments. 

Conservative Treatment Options for Lateral Foot Pain 

Many cases of lateral foot pain can be treated without surgery. Rest is often the first step in treatment. Giving your foot time to heal can help reduce inflammation and pain. 

Applying ice to the affected area can help reduce swelling and numb pain. You can do this for 15-20 minutes at a time, several times a day. Just be sure to wrap the ice in a towel to protect your skin. 

Over-the-counter pain medications like ibuprofen or naproxen can help manage pain and reduce inflammation. However, it's always best to consult with a healthcare provider before starting any new medication. 

Physical therapy can be very effective for treating lateral foot pain. A physical therapist can teach you exercises to strengthen the muscles in your foot and ankle, improving stability and reducing the risk of future injuries. 

Prevention Strategies for Lateral Foot Pain 

Preventing lateral foot pain is often easier than treating it. There are several steps you can take to reduce your risk of developing this issue. 

Wearing proper footwear with supportive insoles is crucial. Choose shoes that fit well and insoles like Superfeet that offer structured support under you arches and around your heels. If you're an athlete or engage in high-impact activities, make sure to replace your shoes regularly as they wear out.  

Gradually increasing the intensity and duration of your physical activities can help prevent overuse injuries. If you're starting a new exercise program, give your body time to adjust. 

Stretching and strengthening exercises for your feet and ankles can improve flexibility and stability, reducing your risk of injury. Simple exercises like toe curls or ankle rotations can be done at home and can make a big difference. 

Avoiding Surgery with Proper Foot Care 

While surgery is sometimes necessary for severe cases of lateral foot pain, many people can avoid it with proper care and management. One of the most effective ways to prevent and manage lateral foot pain is by using appropriate footwear and insoles. 

Look for shoes with a wide toe box and insoles with good arch support. Avoid high heels or shoes that put extra pressure on the outer part of your foot. 

Superfeet insoles can make a big difference in managing lateral foot pain. They help distribute pressure more evenly across your foot, reducing strain on the outer edge. They also provide extra cushioning and support where you need it most. 

Lateral Foot Pain Recovery and Help From Superfeet 

With proper treatment and care, the outlook for most cases of lateral foot pain is good. Many people find relief through conservative treatments like rest, physical therapy, and proper footwear with insoles. 

Even after your pain has resolved, continuing with good foot care practices is important. This includes wearing supportive shoes, maintaining strength and flexibility in your feet and ankles, and being mindful of any recurring pain or discomfort. 

At Superfeet, we know the right insole can boost your comfort, health, and performance. Whether your goal is to prevent injury or speed recovery, try our insoles today and feel the difference for yourself. 

Written in consultation with and reviewed by Superfeet Biomechanics and Education team members Meredith Wells, PhD and Justin Wager, PhD
Summary HTML: Pain along the outside of your foot can stem from injuries, overuse, or poor support. Learn how to relieve discomfort and prevent future issues with the right footwear and Superfeet insoles.
Tags: Injury Prevention, Superfeet Wellness, Tips + Tricks

Title: The Best Ways to Relieve Foot Pain from Standing at Work
Author: Carla Vargas
Body HTML:
Standing for hours at work is a reality for millions of professionals across various industries, from healthcare workers and retail employees to chefs and construction workers. While earning a living often requires spending long periods on your feet, the resulting foot pain doesn't have to be an inevitable consequence.   

Luckily, Superfeet insoles can transform your daily experience and improve your overall quality of life. 

Why Standing at Work Can Be So Painful 

Several factors contribute to this common workplace issue: 

Continuous Muscle Engagement and Fatigue 

Unlike walking, where muscles get brief moments of rest between steps, standing keeps your foot and leg muscles constantly engaged to maintain balance and support. This continuous engagement leads to muscle fatigue and soreness throughout your shift. 

Poor Circulation and Blood Pooling 

Gravity constantly pulls blood downward, and when you stand for extended periods, blood can pool in your lower legs, ankles, and feet. This makes it difficult for your circulatory system to return blood to your heart efficiently, resulting in swelling, stiffness, and pain. 

Inadequate Footwear Support 

Your choice of work shoes plays a monumental role in foot health. Flat, rigid, or unsupportive footwear can significantly strain your feet. Shoes with narrow toe boxes pinch your toes, while lack of cushioning leads to pain in the forefoot and heel. Worn-out shoes also lose their ability to absorb shock, increasing your risk of various foot problems. 

Poor Posture and Alignment 

When fatigue sets in, many workers adopt suboptimal postures that create muscle imbalances and increased strain on certain foot areas. This "swayback" posture puts extra pressure on your feet and can exacerbate existing discomfort. 

Immediate Relief Strategies for Foot Pain 

When foot pain strikes during or after work, several simple techniques can provide quick relief: 

  • Gentle Stretching and Movement
  • Therapeutic Foot Soaks
  • Cold Therapy Application
  • Elevation and Rest
  • Over-the-Counter Pain Relief 

The Power of Supportive Insoles 

Choosing appropriate footwear is important, but integrating high-quality insoles can be transformative for workers who spend significant time on their feet. Superfeet insoles work by distributing body weight more evenly across the entire foot, reducing concentrated pressure points and providing crucial arch support. 

Scientifically validated performance insoles like Superfeet offer several key benefits: 

  • Enhanced arch support that reduces strain on the plantar fascia
  • Superior shock absorption to protect joints from hard surfaces
  • Improved foot functioning that can benefit your entire kinetic chain
  • Targeted relief for conditions like flat feet, high arches, and plantar fasciitis 

Superfeet Work Cushion insoles deliver anti-fatigue cushioning and flexible arch support making them ideal for workers dealing with prolonged standing demands. 

Written in consultation with and reviewed by Superfeet Biomechanics and Education team members Meredith Wells, PhD and Justin Wager, PhD
Summary HTML: Spending long hours on your feet can cause fatigue, swelling, and soreness. Supportive Superfeet insoles help distribute pressure, improve alignment, and keep you comfortable through every shift.

Title: Flat Feet vs. Normal Arches: What's the Real Difference and How to Find Relief
Author: Superfeet User
Body HTML:
Understanding the difference between flat feet and “normal” arches (a more neutral arch closer to the arch height found on the average foot, although there is nothing abnormal about flat feet) is important for anyone experiencing foot discomfort or seeking to optimize their foot health. Knowing whether you have low, medium or high arches can help you better address problems that might arise based on your arch height and can enable you to find effective solutions quicker and easier.  

Understanding Your Foot's Architecture: The Role of Arches 

There are three main arches in the foot. Proper function of all three is essential for efficient movement and energy conservation during daily activities. 

  • Medial Longitudinal Arch: The most prominent arch running along the inside of your foot from heel to toe 

  • Lateral Longitudinal Arch: Located along the outer edge, providing stability 

  • Transverse Arch: Running across the midfoot, contributing to weight distribution 

Feet with medium-high or neutral arches display a noticeable curve in the central area, lifting the middle portion of the foot off the ground when standing. This natural architecture can have some functional benefits, including: 

  • Efficient shock absorption

  • Balanced weight distribution 

  • Improved stability 

 When you have “normal” arches, your foot is more likely to follow an efficient walking pattern in which the heel contacts the ground first, weight is distributed evenly as the middle and front of the foot land and push off occurs without excessive pressure on the big toe. This is not to say that having flatter arches always leads to foot pain or that people with average arches never experience discomfort but speaks to broad patterns related to arch height and foot health. 

Flat Feet: More Than Just a Missing Arch 

 Flat feet, medically known as pes planus or fallen arches, occur when the inner arch is flattened or absent, causing the entire sole to contact the floor when standing. While all babies are born with flat feet due to extra soft tissue that masks the developing arch, most children develop visible arches by age six. However, some either never form prominent arches, or experience arch collapse later in life. It’s not uncommon to have flat feet as they can result from many things such as genetics, aging, obesity, injury, arthritis, and pregnancy. 

Here are some of the different types of flat feet: 

Flexible Flat Feet: The most common type where the arch appears when not bearing weight but flattens when standing. Often develops in childhood and may worsen with age. 

Rigid Flat Feet: A rarer condition where the arch is absent regardless of weight-bearing status. Usually present from birth or developed during teenage years. 

Adult-Acquired Flat Foot: Occurs when previously neutral arches collapse over time, often due to dysfunction of the posterior tibial tendon (the tendon attached to one of the lower leg muscles). 

Vertical Talus: A rare congenital condition affecting bone positioning that prevents proper arch formation. 

Symptoms and Complications 

While many people with flat feet experience no problems, others face significant physical implications due to altered biomechanics. The primary issue is excessive inward motion of the foot that creates a chain reaction of conditions throughout the body.

Common Symptoms of Problematic Flat Feet: 

  • Foot pain: Particularly in the arch, heel, or ball of the foot 

  • Shin splints: Lower leg muscle stress from altered gait patterns 

  • Knee, hip, and back pain: dysfunction traveling up the kinetic chain 

  • Foot deformities: Higher risk of bunions and hammertoes 

  • Chronic foot and ankle fatigue: Muscles working harder to compensate for lack of natural support 

  • Uneven shoe wear: Particularly on the inner side due to excessive inward motion of the foot 

How to Identify Your Foot Type 

There are a few convenient ways you can check to see if you have flat feet. 

The Wet Footprint Test: 

1. Wet your feet completely 

2. Step onto a piece of cardboard or dark, flat surface 

3. Examine the footprint: 

  • Normal arch: Clear curve on inside edge with middle section about half filled 

  • Flat foot: Nearly complete footprint with little to no curve 

  • High arch: Thin line connecting heel and toes with minimal middle section 

The Finger Test: 

While standing, try sliding fingers under your arch. Easy insertion suggests normal arches, while inability to fit fingers underneath indicates flat feet. 

For comprehensive evaluation, especially if experiencing pain, consult a podiatrist for professional diagnosis and gait analysis. 

How Superfeet Insoles Transform Flat Foot Health 

For individuals struggling with flat foot discomfort, Superfeet premium insoles offer a scientifically designed solution that goes beyond simple cushioning. These structured orthotic supports are engineered to address the root of the problem – anatomically flat feet. 

Pain Relief Through Proper Support 

Superfeet insoles feature a distinctive supportive shape that stabilizes the foot and redistributes pressure evenly across the entire sole. The structured design helps prevent excessive inward motion in each step, helping to address the cascade of symptoms that can affect your entire body. 

Encouraging Natural Foot Strengthening 

While providing external support, Superfeet's innovative design encourages your foot to engage its natural structures more effectively. By stabilizing the heel and supporting the arch, these insoles help your foot operate in a more optimal position.  

Versatile Solutions for Every Lifestyle 

Superfeet offers an extensive range of insoles tailored to different shoe types and activities. Whether you need support for: 

  • Casual and dress shoes 

  • Athletic footwear for running or hiking 

  • Work boots for occupational demands 

  • Winter sports equipment 

This comprehensive selection ensures consistent support and comfort across all aspects of your life, without compromising your active lifestyle. Our insole finder quiz helps you select the perfect Superfeet product for your specific needs and foot type. 

 

For those experiencing discomfort from flat feet, Superfeet insoles represent a proven solution that can provide pain relief and contribute to long-term foot strengthening and improved biomechanics.  

By investing in proper foot support, you're investing in your overall mobility and wellness! 

Written in consultation with and reviewed by Superfeet Biomechanics and Education team members Meredith Wells, PhD and Justin Wager, PhD
Summary HTML: Understanding whether you have flat feet, neutral arches, or high arches can make a big difference in managing foot discomfort and choosing the right footwear. Learn how your arch height affects movement, support needs, and overall foot wellness—so you can take steps toward feeling better, faster.

Title: What are the Best Insoles for Plantar Fasciitis in 2025?
Author: Carla Vargas
Body HTML:
Plantar fasciitis is a common foot condition that affects many. It occurs when the plantar fascia, a thick band of tissue connecting your heel bone to your toes, becomes inflamed. This inflammation leads to sharp pain in the heel and arch of the foot, especially when taking your first steps in the morning or after long periods of rest. 

At Superfeet, we understand the challenges faced by those suffering from plantar fasciitis. The pain can be debilitating, affecting your daily activities and overall quality of life. Many people find themselves unable to enjoy simple pleasures like taking a walk or standing for extended periods without discomfort. 

That's why we've dedicated ourselves to creating solutions that not only alleviate pain but also promote long-term foot health. Our insoles are designed with the latest technology and research to provide targeted support and relief for plantar fasciitis sufferers. 

How Superfeet Insoles Can Help Treat Plantar Fasciitis 

Structured insoles can play a crucial role in managing plantar fasciitis by providing supportive shape underneath your feet. Superfeet insoles are anatomically designed to deliver support right where your feet need it most, redistributing pressure across your foot and reducing strain on the plantar fascia. Superfeet are proven to reduce strain on the plantar fascia by up to 24%. This not only provides immediate relief but also contributes to long-term healing and prevention of future flare-ups. 

Our insoles also feature shock-absorbing materials that minimize the impact of each step, further reducing stress on the plantar fascia. This is especially beneficial for those who spend long hours on their feet or engage in high-impact activities. 

Key Features of Superfeet Insoles for Plantar Fasciitis 

Superfeet insoles utilize several key features to specifically address the needs of plantar fasciitis sufferers: 

  1. Stabilizing Arch Support: Our insoles are designed with contoured arch support, providing stability and reducing strain on the plantar fascia. 

  1. Advanced Cushioning Technology: We use high-quality, shock-absorbing materials to cushion the heel and forefoot, minimizing impact and providing all-day comfort. 

  1. Structured Heel Cup: Made with durable materials, the rearfoot support of Superfeet position the natural soft tissue in your heel to reduce fatigue and absorb vibrations. 

These features work together to create a comprehensive solution for plantar fasciitis, addressing both the symptoms and underlying causes of the condition. 

How Superfeet Insoles Provide Relief 

When you slip a pair of Superfeet insoles into your shoes, you'll immediately notice the difference. The contoured shape provides instant support and comfort. As you walk, the insoles work to distribute pressure evenly across your foot, reducing strain on the plantar fascia. 

The heel cup in our insoles helps to stabilize your foot, reducing excessive pronation (inward rolling of the foot) which can exacerbate plantar fasciitis symptoms. This stability, combined with the cushioning in the heel area, helps to absorb shock and reduce pain with each step. 

Over time, consistent use of our insoles can lead to significant improvements in plantar fasciitis symptoms. Many wearers report reduced pain, increased mobility, and a better overall quality of life after incorporating Superfeet insoles into their daily routine. 

Incorporating Superfeet Insoles into Your Daily Routine 

To get the most benefit from your Superfeet insoles, it's important to incorporate them into your daily routine gradually. Here are some tips to help you get started: 

  1. Start Slow: Begin by wearing your insoles for a few hours each day, gradually increasing the duration as your feet adjust. 

  1. Use in Every Shoe: For consistent support, use your insoles in all your frequently worn shoes. 

  1. Replace Regularly: While our insoles are built to last, it's important to replace them every 12-18 months or when you notice a decrease in support. 

  1. Combine with Stretching: Pair your insole use with gentle foot stretches to further alleviate plantar fasciitis symptoms. 

  1. Maintain Proper Footwear: Even with insoles, it's important to wear supportive shoes that complement the insoles' function. 

By following these guidelines, you'll maximize the benefits of your Superfeet insoles and take significant steps towards managing your plantar fasciitis. 

Additional Benefits of Superfeet Insoles 

While our insoles are excellent for managing plantar fasciitis, their benefits extend beyond this specific condition. Many wearers report improvements in overall foot health, posture, and comfort. Here are some additional benefits you might experience: 

  1. Reduced Fatigue 

  1. Improved Athletic Performance 

  1. Increased Comfort in Various Shoes 

  1. Prevention of Other Foot Issues 

Why Choose Superfeet for Your Plantar Fasciitis Relief? 

With decades of experience and a commitment to ongoing research and development, we're at the forefront of orthotic technology. Our insoles are the result of extensive study, innovative design, and a deep understanding of foot biomechanics. You don’t become the most scientifically tested, researched and validated insoles in the world by accident. We’re dedicated to alleviating foot pain and increasing performance for everyone, whether you’re going for gold or just going for a walk. 

Written in consultation with and reviewed by Superfeet Biomechanics and Education team members Meredith Wells, PhD and Justin Wager, PhD
Summary HTML: Plantar fasciitis causes sharp heel and arch pain that can disrupt your daily life. Superfeet insoles are designed to reduce strain, absorb shock, and provide long-term relief so you can move with less discomfort.

Title: Why High Arches Can Lead to High Instep Foot
Author: Superfeet User
Body HTML:
Why High Arches Can Lead to High Instep Foot

Feet with high arches mean that less of the surface of the foot is connected to the ground, and the parts that do make weight-bearing contact have more stress on the heel and the ball of the foot. As you might guess, this can create painful conditions.

But what about the top of the foot?  

The other side of the foot of someone who has high arches often develops a corresponding high instep, meaning there is a more pronounced ridge on the top of the foot. While this isn’t always the case, and high insteps can occur separately, it generally means that whatever the cause, the top of the foot will have more volume, taking up more space in your shoe. 

What Causes High Instep Foot? 

Because they are anatomically related to each other, many of the same root causes of high arches may also produce high instep foot. 

The shape of your feet is determined, for the most part, by your genes. High instep foot can be inherited. In other cases, neurological conditions, such as muscular dystrophy, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, polio, spina bifida, and cerebral palsy, can create high arches that lead to high instep feet.    

Muscular imbalances such as clubfoot or injuries like broken bones or spinal cord damage can also cause high arch and high instep foot conditions, including toe deformities like claw toes or hammertoes.  

On a practical side, people suffering from high instep foot generally have difficulty finding comfortable shoes that fit correctly because the top of the foot may be too high for standard shoe sizes. Specially designed shoes should have extra volume and depth to accommodate high instep foot abnormalities. 

What Are the Treatment Options for High Instep Foot? 

Treatment often focuses on managing pain and improving stability through various options. 

Insoles and Orthotics: Shoe inserts provide cushioning and arch support that evenly redistributes weight across the foot, reducing stress and strain on the ball and the heel, resulting in less pain throughout the foot. You can buy insoles over the counter, or a podiatrist can prescribe custom-fitting orthotics for you. 

Shoes: Footwear with supportive insoles and a wider toe box create more room and less pressure on high insteps and arches. Shoes with a lot of additional arch support are not a good solution because they can push a high instep even higher. Shoes and custom orthotics work best when they are thoughtfully paired together. 

Physical Therapy: This can take many forms, from stretching exercises that reduce tightness in the arches and exercises that strengthen foot and ankle muscles to using night splits, ankle braces, and icing to reduce pain and inflammation. Over-the-counter medications can also provide additional relief. 

Surgery: When other forms of treatment don’t work, and if the pain and inflammation are chronic, surgery may be warranted. Depending on the root cause, surgical options may include joint fusion, reshaping bones (osteotomy), or lengthening tendons to increase flexibility and range of movement associated with high arches. Modifying high arches can be the key to lessening the impacts of high instep feet. 

Without proper care, a high instep foot can lead to additional chronic foot and joint pain and nerve damage. However, with attentive treatment, many people manage this condition and lead healthy, normal lives. 

Choosing the Right Superfeet Insoles Based on Arch Height   

An effective way to lessen the pain of high arches and high instep foot is to use the proper orthotics. Comfort is the key, but choosing the right insoles also depends on the type of footwear you’ll be wearing them in. 

For example, an athlete with high arches may wear Run Support Low Arch insoles in specific slim-fitting footwear because having a Superfeet shape that fits the best is better than not having that support in every step. 

Superfeet insoles at any arch height usually fit well in most shoes with removable liners. If you are new to wearing Superfeet or are unsure which arch height will be most comfortable, try a medium arch insole like Run Cushion Medium Arch or All-Purpose Support Medium Arch. You can always try a pair designed for all arch heights (and made with memory foam cushioning) like Casual Support insoles. 

No matter your arch height, cushioning preference, or type of footwear, Superfeet insoles can provide that missing support that perfectly fits between the contoured shape of your feet and the flat surface inside your shoes.
Summary HTML: High arches can lead to high instep foot, a condition that adds pressure to the top of the foot and makes finding comfortable footwear a challenge. This article explains the causes, symptoms, and treatment options—including how Superfeet insoles can help redistribute pressure, improve stability, and provide lasting comfort. Learn how the right support can make a big difference in managing high instep foot pain.
Tags: Injury Prevention, Superfeet Wellness, Tips + Tricks

Title: Tailor's Bunion: Find Prevention Tips and Pain Relief with Superfeet Insoles
Author: Superfeet User
Body HTML:
Tailor's Bunion: Find Prevention Tips and Pain Relief with Superfeet Insoles

A tailor's bunion, also known as a bunionette, is a bony bump that forms on the outer side of the foot near the base of the little toe. 

Unlike a regular bunion that affects the big toe, this condition specifically involves the fifth metatarsal bone. 

The name "tailor's bunion" comes from the past when tailors would sit cross-legged for long periods, putting pressure on the outside of their feet. 

This condition can cause discomfort, pain, and difficulty wearing certain types of shoes. The bump may become red, swollen, and inflamed, especially when rubbed against footwear. Tailor's bunions develop gradually over time and can affect people of all ages, though they are more common in adults. 

While not as well-known as their bigger counterparts, tailor's bunions can significantly impact a person's quality of life if left untreated.  

What Can Cause a Tailor's Bunion? 

One of the primary causes is inherited foot structure. Some people are born with a foot shape that makes them more prone to developing this condition. For instance, having a wider forefoot or a tendency for the fifth metatarsal bone to angle outward can increase the risk. Wearing ill-fitting shoes, particularly those that are too tight or narrow in the toe box, can exacerbate the problem.  

Other contributing factors include:

  • Arthritis, which can cause joint damage and deformity
  • Trauma or injury to the foot
  • Certain occupations that require prolonged standing or walking
  • Age-related changes in foot structure 

It's important to note that while these factors can increase the likelihood of developing a tailor's bunion, not everyone with these risk factors will necessarily develop the condition. 

How Superfeet Insoles Can Help You with Tailor’s Bunion Symptoms 

Superfeet insoles are designed to redistribute impact forces and therefore can be critical in managing existing bunion pain and swelling, as well as preventing further changes to the foot. When we’re hard on our feet or wearing shoes that are too tight or lacking in support, bunion symptoms can be exacerbated. 

If you notice you’ve developed any tailor’s bunions, know that the correct insole can relieve pain and make any shoes more wearable. 

Symptoms and Finding a Diagnosis  

The most obvious sign of a tailor's bunion is the visible bump on the outer side of the foot near the base of the little toe. However, there are several other symptoms that may accompany this condition: 

  • Pain or tenderness at the site of the bump
  • Redness and swelling around the affected area
  • Difficulty finding comfortable shoes
  • Calluses or corns where the bump rubs against shoes
  • Changes in the alignment of the little toe 

Diagnosing a tailor's bunion typically involves a physical examination by a healthcare professional, usually a podiatrist or orthopedic specialist. They will assess the foot structure, check for signs of inflammation, and evaluate the range of motion in the affected joint. 

In some cases, X-rays may be ordered to get a clearer picture of the bone structure and to determine the severity of the condition. This imaging can help the doctor assess the angle of the fifth metatarsal bone and plan the most appropriate treatment. 

Conservative Treatment Options 

For many people with tailor's bunions, conservative treatments can provide significant relief. These non-surgical approaches focus on reducing pain, preventing further progression of the deformity, and improving overall foot comfort. 

One of the first steps in managing a tailor's bunion is to wear appropriate footwear. Shoes with a wide toe box and soft, flexible materials can help reduce pressure on the affected area. Avoiding high heels and tight shoes is also crucial in preventing further irritation. 

Other conservative treatment options include: 

  • Padding or cushioning the bunion to reduce friction
  • Using orthotic devices to help redistribute pressure and improve foot alignment
  • Applying ice to reduce swelling and discomfort
  • Taking over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen to manage pain and inflammation
  • Performing specific exercises to maintain joint flexibility and strengthen foot muscles 

In some cases, a doctor may recommend wearing a splint at night to help realign the toe and reduce pressure on the joint. While these treatments can't reverse the bony deformity, they can often provide significant symptom relief and slow the progression of the condition. 

Preventing Tailor's Bunions for Runners and Athletes 

Runners and athletes are particularly prone to bunionettes due to prolonged high-impact stress on the foot, and oftentimes, improper footwear. The good news is that there are ways to keep your feet healthy and protect your bones, even if you ask a lot of them. 

One of the most effective prevention strategies is wearing properly fitting shoes with a wide toe box to reduce pressure on the fifth metatarsal bone. Avoid shoes that are too narrow or have excessive arch compression, as they can force the foot into unnatural positions.  

And we’ll say it one more time: correct and comfortable insoles can play a crucial role in preventing tailor’s bunions. Superfeet insoles distribute force to reduce strain and support the arch to improve foot alignment.  

Regular foot-strengthening exercises and stretches, such as toe spreads and calf stretches, can improve foot flexibility and reduce strain. Taping techniques or using padding in problem areas can also offer relief. By taking these proactive steps, runners and athletes can significantly lower their risk of developing tailor’s bunions. 

Living with a Tailor's Bunion 

Managing a tailor's bunion is often an ongoing process. Even after treatment, whether conservative or surgical, it's important to continue practicing good foot care habits to prevent recurrence or worsening of symptoms. 

Some tips for living comfortably with a tailor's bunion include: 

  • Regularly stretching and exercising your feet to maintain flexibility
  • Using ice therapy after long periods of standing or walking to reduce inflammation
  • Wearing supportive, comfortable shoes and avoiding footwear that puts pressure on the affected area
  • Maintaining a healthy lifestyle to reduce overall stress on your feet 

By staying proactive about your foot health and working closely with healthcare professionals, you can effectively manage a tailor's bunion and maintain an active, comfortable lifestyle. Remember, every case is unique, so what works best for you may require some trial and error in consultation with your doctor.
Summary HTML: A tailor’s bunion, or bunionette, is a painful bump on the outside of the foot near the little toe, often caused by foot structure, tight shoes, or repetitive stress. This article explains how Superfeet insoles can help relieve pressure, reduce pain, and prevent further irritation by improving foot alignment and support. Learn about symptoms, treatment options, and prevention tips—especially for runners and active individuals.

Title: How to Prevent and Treat Pain from High Arch Feet
Author: Superfeet User
Body HTML:
How to Prevent and Treat Pain from High Arch Feet 

High arch feet are a common condition also referred to as pes cavus or cavus foot. High arches refer to the longitudinal arch on the inside of the foot that runs from the ball and the heel of the foot. Typically, a foot rolls from the outside of the foot toward the inside when you step on it to help absorb shocks and deal with uneven surfaces. 

But with high arches, feet do not roll easily. Instead, to compensate for the pain associated with this condition, people with high arches often stand and walk on the outside of their foot, potentially creating more health issues. 

Abnormally high arches mean less of the foot makes contact with the ground due to a larger-than-normal gap between the two versus a moderately curved arch that creates optimal ground contact and weight distribution. 

High arches are characterized by rigid and inflexible feet that hinder mobility and the ability to absorb shocks necessary for pain-free walking and running. Without adequate flexibility, uneven weight distribution on the ball and heel of the foot occurs, creating pain and instability. 

High Arch Feet Causes and Complications 

Some children develop high arches early in life naturally or as an inherited condition. Some babies are born with congenital muscle contractures, such as clubfoot, that can cause high arches as they grow. 

However, high arches can develop anytime due to bone and nerve injuries or diseases such as muscular dystrophy, cerebral palsy, spina bifida, polio, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, diabetes-related neuropathy, and others. When it is due to neurological conditions, high arches are likely to worsen over time.  

If it’s mild, high arches may not cause any issues. However, many people with high arches are also more prone to painful calluses, corns, claw toes, hammertoes, feet, ankle and knee injuries, including sprains and broken bones. Pain can also be caused by plantar fasciitis, an inflammation of the plantar fascia, a ligament that runs along the bottom of the foot, connects the heel bone to the toes, and supports the arch.  

Other common complications are metatarsalgia, an inflammation of the ball of the foot that causes sharp and shooting pains, and peroneal tendonitis, an inflammation of a tendon in the outer ankle. Foot and ankle arthritis may develop over the long term as well. 

Naturally occurring muscle weaknesses and imbalances in feet and lower legs may also contribute to the development of high arches. Until the problem is corrected, people with high arches may discover their shoes lose their form or wear out more quickly due to uneven shock absorption.

An accurate diagnosis is the first step in the right course of treatment for high arches. Working with a podiatrist or orthopedist is essential to finding the best solution that minimizes pain and restores mobility and stability.  

Treatment Options for High Arch Feet 

A podiatrist can diagnose high arches through a physical examination that checks the shape of the arch, shoe wear, walking patterns, and more. Sometimes, an X-ray or other tests may be needed to determine the cause. 

The severity of the pain and instability will often dictate the type of treatment required.  

One of the most common forms of treatment is orthotics that provide support for high arches.  These form-fitted shoe inserts should have foam cushioning to provide maximum shock absorption, especially in the ball of the foot where pressure and discomfort are often the highest. They can also be flexible to avoid creating pressure points and should have a heel stabilization element to assist with proper foot alignment.  

The orthotic should also fully contact the foot’s natural arch to lessen the overall impact of high arches. These inserts may also be paired with custom-made or corrective braces, splints, or shoes that could include a brace or high tops to increase stability. 

Physical therapy that strengthens and improves muscle flexibility may also be prescribed. Over-the-counter medications such as nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can also ease pain and swelling. 

Another simple way to lessen the impacts of high arches is to maintain a healthy weight.  Keeping extra pounds off reduces the stress on toes, feet, ankles, and knees, naturally lessening high arch pain. 

Surgery to flatten the foot and correct major deformities in severe cases may be the recommended treatment. Other surgical options may include realigning other bones, replacing a non-functioning tendon, fusing bones together, or making small soft tissue cuts to relieve tension. 

Rehabilitation after surgery is vital to its long-term success, meaning following your doctor’s post-surgical treatment plan is essential. That may include continued physical therapy or other exercises for as long as is needed.     

Which Superfeet Insoles Work Best for High Arches? 

To find the right Superfeet, start with your shoes. What type of shoes are you wearing? What are you doing in those shoes?  

We think you deserve to experience the I-never-knew-my-feet-could-feel-this-good benefits of the Superfeet shape in all your footwear. That’s why we make insoles for casual and dress shoes, shoe inserts for high heels, insoles for hiking, insoles for running shoes, insoles for snow sports, insoles for skates, and more. 

No matter your arch height, cushioning preference, or type of footwear, Superfeet insoles can provide that missing piece of support that perfectly fits between the contoured shape of your feet and the flat surface inside your shoes. 

Need help finding the best Superfeet for you? Take the online insole finder quiz.
Summary HTML: High arches can lead to pain, instability, and long-term foot complications if left untreated. This article explores the causes, symptoms, and treatment options for high arch feet, including how Superfeet insoles provide essential support, cushioning, and alignment to relieve pressure and improve comfort. Discover how the right insole can make a big difference in managing high arches and staying active.

Title: What You Should Know About Outside Ankle Pain
Author: Superfeet User
Body HTML:
What You Should Know About Outside Ankle Pain   

Outside ankle pain, also referred to as chronic lateral ankle pain, is recurring pain on the outer side of the ankle that often develops after an injury such as a sprain or a chronic condition like arthritis or a foot deformity.   

The pain may range from a dull ache to sharp and intense shooting pain that makes walking or running extremely difficult, if not impossible. That pain is usually accompanied by tenderness, swelling, bruising, stiffness, and inflamed tendons around the ankle.

What Causes Ankle Pain? 

There are several possible causes of ankle pain, including simply standing or walking on your feet all day. In broad terms, outside ankle pain is present for two main reasons. The first is injuries that flair up and are directly related to improper or repetitive stress on the ankle or outer foot. This can include: 

Ankle sprain: Sprained ankles are among the most common ankle injuries. They can range from mild to severe and are caused by a stressful or sudden roll or twist of the ankle. Sometimes, sprains also tear ligaments, creating further problems that can require an extended healing period. 

Bone fracture: Fractures can occur due to a sudden and violent injury, resulting in a clean break of the bone, or a stress fracture caused by repeated overuse that produces a small, painful break or crack in the bone. 

Achilles tendonitis: The Achilles tendon is a tissue band connecting your calf muscles on the back of your lower leg to your heel bone. Achilles tendonitis results from an overuse injury in the heel, usually due to too much exercise, running, or walking. Pain can vary from mild to intense and will radiate up the ankle. 

Peroneal tendonitis: This occurs when the tendons running along the outer side of your ankle and foot become inflamed through overuse or acute injuries.    

Cuboid syndrome: This injury occurs when the cuboid bone on the outer side of your foot becomes dislocated or misaligned. The cuboid bone helps stabilize your foot and is connected to your ankle, playing an important role in your foot’s stability. This condition is often caused by overuse, being overweight, or simply wearing tight shoes. It is usually treated using orthotics, physical therapy, or resting your feet until the condition heals. 

The second broad category includes chronic conditions or ongoing non-stress related issues that can include: 

Arthritis: This condition is caused by joint inflammation and may be attributed to injuries, age, or conditions such as gout that result in stiffness and pain in joints, including the ankle. 

Gout: This is a form of arthritis caused by a buildup of uric acid in the joints. It is most common in the foot and ankle. 

Flat feet: This condition is when the arch in the foot is low or non-existent, producing added stress on the foot and ankle. 

Bunions: These are bony bumps that form near the big toe joint, causing it to angle toward your other toes, eventually putting pressure on the outside edge of your foot. Bunions can be caused by genetic issues or poorly fitted shoes. 

Bursitis: This condition is similar to arthritis and is caused by inflammation of the fluid-filled sacs in your joints called bursae, causing pain, swelling, and stiffness. 

Tarsal coalition: A congenital condition in which bones are abnormally fused in the back of your foot, resulting in stiffness and pain. 

Sural nerve entrapment: This is more commonly known as a pinched nerve, which can be temporary or long-lasting, depending on the cause and severity. Most pinched nerves are treated with rest, over-the-counter medication, and physical therapy. 

Treating Outside Ankle Pain 

Many common forms of ankle pain are treated with rest, ice, compression, and elevation to reduce inflammation and get you back on your feet. Applying a cold pack to the affected area for 20 minutes several times daily and wrapping the ankle in an elastic bandage to provide gentle support are effective treatments. You should also elevate your painful ankle above your heart level to minimize swelling if possible. These actions, coupled with over-the-counter pain medication such as Tylenol or Ibuprofen, help speed up the healing process. 

For persistent and chronic pain, it's essential to seek professional medical help through a podiatrist or orthopedic specialist. More intense forms of outside ankle pain may require a detailed diagnosis and targeted treatment plan. Consult a doctor if your ankle pain is due to a sudden injury or if it is not getting better after three days of self-care at home. 

Insoles Offer Many Healing Advantages 

Insoles are among the most effective ways to deal with many forms of ankle pain, especially for minor injuries or those diagnosed where an orthotic device is recommended or prescribed. 

Supportive insoles can add stability and relieve pressure on conditions such as gout or tendonitis. Alternatively, if you keep wearing shoes that lack support for your ankles, you could worsen your condition or injury. 

The most effective insoles for treating ankle pain have a deep heel cup. This cradles the heel and supports the arch while supporting the ankle. Insoles should be worn with appropriate footwear that is somewhat rigid as opposed to being too soft or flimsy. 

Insoles also help improve posture and balance, creating better overall stability. When weight is distributed correctly, it also helps prevent injuries or reduces the possibility of aggravating existing injuries. These orthotics can also alleviate other body pain that may be occurring in the knees, hips, and back. 

Surgery as an Option

If other options don’t improve your condition, your doctor may recommend an injection of a steroid medication or joint aspiration, which involves inserting a needle into your ankle to remove excess fluid that causes swelling. 

For more challenging conditions, surgery is an option. The specific type of surgery depends on the diagnosis and cause of your ankle pain.  

Surgical treatments may include removing loose bone and tissue fragments, debriding the joint or joint surface, or repairing and reconstructing ligaments to strengthen the ankle area. Some surgeries are more involved than others, but many procedures can be done on an outpatient basis using arthroscopic procedures. Physical therapy after surgery is generally part of the healing process.
Summary HTML: Outside ankle pain—often caused by injuries like sprains or conditions such as tendonitis or arthritis—can significantly impact mobility and comfort. This article explores common causes, treatment options, and how Superfeet supportive insoles can relieve pressure, improve stability, and help prevent further injury. Learn how the right footwear and care can make a lasting difference in managing ankle pain.
Tags: Injury Prevention, Superfeet Wellness, Tips + Tricks

Title: How to Strengthen Chronic Ankle Instability With Superfeet Insoles
Author: Superfeet User
Body HTML:
How to Strengthen Chronic Ankle Instability With Superfeet Insoles 

Chronic ankle instability is a common condition that affects many people, especially those who have experienced repeated ankle sprains. It occurs when the outer side of the ankle repeatedly gives way, leading to persistent discomfort and a feeling of the ankle being wobbly or unstable. This condition can make simple activities like walking on uneven surfaces challenging and increase the risk of future ankle injuries. 

The main cause of chronic ankle instability is usually a previous ankle sprain that didn't heal properly. When an ankle sprain occurs, it can stretch or tear the ligaments that help stabilize the ankle joint. If these ligaments don't heal correctly or the muscles around the ankle become weak, it can lead to ongoing instability. 

Many people with this condition report feeling like their ankle might "give out" at any moment. This uncertainty can affect daily activities and even limit participation in sports or exercise. 

How Superfeet Insoles Help with Ankle Instability 

Custom insoles can be highly effective in managing ankle instability by providing targeted support and alignment. We’ve designed our insole to stabilize the foot by correcting biomechanical imbalances such as overpronation. Correct foot alignment reduces excessive motion that can lead to ankle rolling or sprains.  

Superfeet insoles offer enhanced arch support, promoting proper weight distribution and reducing strain on the ankle joint. Having the right insole can even improve balance and coordination, which is crucial for individuals with weak or unstable ankles. By promoting proper foot mechanics, Superfeet helps prevent recurrent ankle injuries and improve overall stability during movement. 

Common Symptoms of Chronic Ankle Instability 

Recognizing the symptoms of chronic ankle instability is the first step towards getting proper treatment. The most common signs include: 

  1. A repeated feeling of the ankle "giving way," especially on uneven surfaces or during physical activity 

  1. Persistent discomfort or pain in the ankle 

  1. Ongoing swelling or tenderness 

  1. Difficulty walking on uneven ground or performing activities that require ankle stability 

  1. A sense of weakness in the ankle 

These symptoms can vary in intensity from person to person. Some individuals might experience mild discomfort and occasional instability, while others may have more severe pain and frequent episodes of the ankle giving way. 

It's important to note that symptoms may worsen over time if left untreated. This can lead to additional ankle sprains, further weakening the ligaments and increasing instability. If you're experiencing any of these symptoms, especially if they persist for more than a few weeks after an ankle sprain, it's crucial to seek medical attention. 

Causes and Risk Factors 

The primary cause of ankle instability is usually one or more poorly healed ankle sprains. When an ankle sprain occurs, it can damage the ligaments that provide stability to the joint. If these ligaments don't heal properly, it can lead to ongoing instability. 

Several factors can increase the risk of developing chronic ankle instability: 

  1. Repeated ankle sprains: Each sprain can further weaken the ligaments, making future sprains more likely. 

  1. Inadequate rehabilitation after a sprain: Not following a proper rehab program can lead to weak ankles and poor balance. 

  1. High-impact sports participation: Activities like basketball, soccer, or tennis that involve frequent jumping and quick direction changes put more stress on the ankles. 

  1. Certain foot structures: People with high arches or feet that roll inward (overpronation) may be more prone to ankle instability. 

  1. Poor balance or proprioception: Reduced ability to sense the position of your ankle in space can contribute to instability. 

It's worth noting that not everyone who experiences an ankle sprain will develop chronic instability. However, those who have had multiple sprains or who didn't receive proper treatment for their initial injury are at higher risk. 

Which Shoes and Insoles Should I Choose to Best Manage Chronic Ankle Instability? 

Made with high-quality materials and innovative technology, Superfeet insoles are anatomically designed to reduce strain on the foot, and therefore on the whole body. While they’re the perfect choice for athletes and runners, they can help anyone looking to strengthen their ankles, and can increase comfort whether you’re wearing dress shoes, everyday sneakers, or hiking boots.  

Treatment for chronic ankle instability often begins with conservative methods. The goal is to strengthen the ankle, improve balance and proprioception, and prevent further injury. Here are some common treatment options: 

  1. Physical Therapy: This is often the first line of treatment. A physical therapist can design a program to:
    • Strengthen the muscles around your ankle 
    • Improve your balance and proprioception
    • Enhance your range of motion 
    • Teach you proper techniques for activities that stress your ankle 

  1. Bracing: Wearing an ankle brace during activities can provide extra support and help prevent the ankle from giving way. 

  1. Medications: Over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or naproxen can help manage pain and reduce inflammation. 

  1. RICE Method: Rest, Ice, Compression, and Elevation can help manage symptoms, especially after a flare-up. 

  2. Lifestyle Modifications: This might include changing your exercise routine or wearing more supportive shoes. 

If conservative treatments don't provide sufficient relief, your doctor might recommend more advanced options: 

  1. Regenerative Medicine: Treatments like platelet-rich plasma (PRP) injections aim to promote healing in the damaged ligaments. 

  1. Surgery: In severe cases or when conservative treatments fail, surgery might be necessary. Surgical options include: 

    • Ligament repair or reconstruction
    • Tendon grafting
    • Ankle arthroscopy to remove loose fragments or scar tissue 

The choice of treatment depends on the severity of your condition, your activity level, and your personal goals. It's important to work closely with your healthcare provider to develop a treatment plan that's right for you. 

Prevention Strategies 

Preventing chronic ankle instability starts with proper care for initial ankle sprains and ongoing ankle health maintenance. Here are some strategies to help prevent this condition: 

  1. Proper Rehabilitation: If you suffer an ankle sprain, follow your doctor's or physical therapist's instructions carefully. Complete the full course of rehabilitation exercises to ensure your ankle heals properly and regains strength. 

  1. Strengthen Your Ankles: Even if you haven't had a sprain, exercises to strengthen the muscles around your ankles can help prevent instability. Try calf raises, ankle circles, and resistance band exercises. 

  1. Improve Balance and Proprioception: Practice standing on one foot, use a balance board, or try yoga to improve your overall balance and ankle stability. 

  1. Wear Appropriate Footwear: Choose shoes that provide good support for your activities. Consider using ankle braces or taping your ankles during high-risk activities, especially if you've had previous sprains. 

  1. Warm Up Properly: Before exercising or playing sports, take time to warm up your ankles with gentle stretches and movements. 

  1. Be Mindful of Surfaces: Pay attention to the surfaces you're walking or exercising on. Uneven terrain can increase the risk of ankle injuries. 

  1. Maintain a Healthy Weight: Excess weight puts additional stress on your ankles, increasing the risk of injury and instability. 

  1. Listen to Your Body: If you feel pain or instability in your ankle, don't ignore it. Rest and seek medical advice if symptoms persist. 

Remember, prevention is always better than cure. By taking these steps, you can significantly reduce your risk of developing chronic ankle instability and maintain healthy, stable ankles for your daily activities and athletic pursuits. 

Long-Term Outlook and Management 

The long-term outlook for individuals with chronic ankle instability can vary depending on the severity of the condition and how well it's managed.  

With proper treatment and ongoing care, many people can significantly improve their symptoms and return to their normal activities.
Summary HTML: Chronic ankle instability can make everyday movement difficult and increase the risk of future injuries, especially after repeated sprains. This article explores how Superfeet insoles support proper foot alignment, reduce strain, and improve balance—helping to stabilize weak ankles and prevent further injury. Learn how the right insoles, combined with smart prevention and treatment strategies, can restore confidence in every step.
Tags: Injury Prevention, Superfeet Wellness, Tips + Tricks

Title: Superfeet Celebrates New Direction
Author: Superfeet User
Body HTML:
Superfeet Celebrates New Direction

On May 6, 2025, Superfeet welcomed journalists, creators, retailers, industry leaders, team members, and one very special guest to an exclusive event in New York City unveiling the future of the brand. Attendees previewed the new brand direction and were some of the first people in the world to get a hands-on preview of upcoming insoles engineered to power athletes in new and impactful ways. The event also included keynote presentations from Trip Randall, CEO, Matt Gooch, VP of Product and Innovation, and Mike Donnelly, VP of Marketing, who had the privilege of welcoming Olympic gold medalist Sanya Richards-Ross to the Superfeet team.

A Bold New Look

The future of Superfeet was on full display at the event. Even passersby got a glimpse of the new logo and brand direction from the sidewalk thanks to full-size window decals. Inside the cavernous space, multiple creative exhibits told the story of the brand and showcased new technologies and product innovations. From 3D printers and foot scanning tech to new ultralight insoles displayed in a box of feathers and puncture resistant insoles above a bed of nails, there was no denying the excitement in the air for major product launches and fitting solutions coming soon.

Welcome Sanya Richards-Ross

One of the most exciting moments of the event was the partnership announcement welcoming four-time Olympic gold medalist Sanya Richards-Ross to the Superfeet team. Sanya is the perfect embodiment of the future of Superfeet both because of her incredible accomplishments on the world stage and in her current role as entrepreneur, broadcaster, and mother.

“Performance isn’t just about crossing the finish line first. It’s about showing up every day with strength, confidence, and heart,” Sanya noted. “I’m proud to partner with Superfeet. They are a brand that supports the athlete in us all. From the track to running a business to chasing my kids around, Superfeet keeps me moving with purpose and power every step of the way.”

Powering the Athlete in You

As Sanya touched on, one theme throughout the event was the idea of powering the athlete in everyone, whether you’re going for gold, working a double shift, or hustling across your city. Your field of play could be a baseball diamond, a factory floor, or the sidewalks and subways connecting where you are now to where you want to be. However you make moves, you’re an athlete, and every step is vital. Our vision for the future centers around powering you forward. As Superfeet CEO Trip Randall said in his opening remarks, “Everything we do begins with the athlete.”

And we’re just getting started.
Summary HTML: On May 6, 2025, Superfeet welcomed journalists, creators, retailers, industry leaders, team members, and one very special guest to an exclusive event in New York City unveiling the future of the brand.
